newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Philips Q2 earnings seen sharply higher.
newsitem.headline: Philips Q2 earnings seen sharply higher.

text.p: Philips Electronics NV is expected to report a rise of about 60 percent in net profit from ordinary operations on Thursday.
Analysts say the sharp rise in earnings will be driven by the sale and closure of loss-making units, restructuring and cost-cutting measures and a stronger dollar.

Their estimates of ordinary net profit range from 429 to 540 million guilders ($240 million to $300 million), with a consensus around 490 million. This compares with 304 million in the second quarter of 1996.
Analysts expect earnings growth to continue in the second half of the year and in both 1998 and 1999.
Philips shares have soared this year, reflecting investors' faith in new chairman Cor Boonstra's ability to raise the profitability of Europe's biggest consumer electronics group.
Since the end of 1996, Philips shares have risen over 120 percent, strongly outperforming the AEX index of Dutch blue chip stocks which itself has chalked up a rise of some 47 percent.
Despite their rapid ascent, analysts say Philips shares are by no means overvalued at current levels of around 150 guilders.
"Philips is in much better shape and there will be a further improvement in the coming years. Profitability will reach a structurally higher level," said Steven Vrolijk of ING Barings.
Vrolijk said that while previous chairman Jan Timmer had to be given credit for keeping Philips afloat, Boonstra had begun to turn Philips into a more efficient and profitable group.
Simon Street of BZW in London said the expected rise in second-quarter earnings was part of a more durable improvement.
"We don't think it's a flash in the pan. We think there will be a progressive improvement quarter by quarter relative to 1996," he said.
Cost-cutting and more efficient production, particularly in the core Sound and Vision consumer electronics business, are expected to be a key factor behind higher earnings.
Philips has launched a major drive to reduce the number of external component suppliers and cut its purchasing costs.
The gradual severance of links with loss-making German firm Grundig is also seen lifting earnings in this sector.

Analysts expect reduced start-up losses from Philips' consumer telephones business and increased earnings from information technology services unit Origin whose earnings were depressed last year by integration costs after a merger.
Vrolijk says that at roughly 22 times his 1997 earnings per share (EPS) estimate of 7.00 guilders, Philips shares are slightly less expensive than the Dutch stock market average.
He rates Philips a buy, expecting EPS to rise to 9.40 guilders in 1998 and 10.85 in 1999, and he believes the share price can reach 175 guilders over the next year.
Street also sees further upside for the shares, predicting that EPS will rise to 10.10 guilders in 1998 from 6.80 in 1997 and 2.11 in 1996.
"On a 12-month view we still think the shares are undervalued," he said. ($ = 1.79 Netherland Antilles Guilders)
